coredata.dc:title: Molecular dynamics study of hydrophobic aggregation in water/methane/methanol systems
coredata.dc:creator: Wallqvist, Anders
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Computer simulations of an initially disordered molecular fluid composed of water and methane exhibit a phase-separation into a cylindrical core of methane molecules surrounded by an aqueous phase. A water/methane/methanol system also supports two phases, with only a weak preferential solvation of the methyl part of methanol into the hydrocarbon-core region. Increasing the pressure decreases the size of the hydrocarbon cylinder but increases the solvation of methanol into the methane phase. At sufficiently high pressures, the phase separation is inhibited by a formation of small methane clusters into water cavities or clathrates.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 182, number 3,4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 2 August 1991 Anders Wallqvist Physical Chemistry 2, Chemical Center, P.O. Box 124, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden Received 17 May 1991 Computer simulations of an initially disordered molecular fluid composed of water and methane exhibit a phase-separation into a cylindrical core of methane molecules surrounded by an aqueous phase. A water/methane/methanol system also supports two phases, with only a weak preferential solvation of the methyl part of methanol into the hydrocarbon-core region. Increasing the pressure decreases the size of the hydrocarbon cylinder but increases the solvation of methanol into the methane phase. At sufficiently high pressures, the phase separation is inhibited by a formation of small methane clusters into water cavities or clathrates. 1. Introduction The assembly of nonpolar molecules in aqueous solution is often referred to as the hydrophobic effect [1 4]. The wide variety of chemical and biological phenomena associated with hydrophobic and am- phiphilic molecules in aqueous solution spans pro- tein folding and membrane stability to tertiary oil recovery. Thus, it is important to be able to model and reproduce properties of the hydrophobic effect on a molecular level with the use of computer sim- ulations. Rigorous calculations of the potential of mean force between two nonpolar solutes in water show no tendency for the solutes to stay together [5 9]. Rather, the hydrogen-bonded nature of liquid water causes the formation of two separate but con- nected hydration cages around the solutes. This en- ables water to minimize the loss of hydrogen bonds associated with the solvation by placing one water molecule directly between the solutes, which can then be hydrogen bonded to three neighboring water mol- ecules [9,10]. In this work, we use a different approach to the problem by using a larger concentration of solutes and varying the pressure to observe the hydrophobic effect in an aqueous solution of methane/methanol mixtures. At a sufficiently high concentration of methane, it will be advantageous for the mixed sys- tem to form two phases containing pure methane in one and a water/methane equilibrium mixture in the other. Such systems lend themselves to the studies of structural ordering of the interface, preferential sol- vation of impurities in either phase, and the stability of the phase separation with regards to perturbations of the system. Since the molecules studied here have low moments of inertia and a low radius of gyration, it is possible to sample the relevant configurations within a reasonable timespan, both in real time and on the computer. Allow pressure, the initially mixed systems sep- arate into an aqueous region where methane is sol- vated by water, and into a methane-rich region where water is excluded from a definite core region. There is no buildup of water structure relative to this hy- drocarbon core, indicating that the perturbation of the liquid-water hydrogen-bond network is small. The solvation of methanol in this system does not indi- cate a strong preference of location in either phase. The tendency for the methyl part of methanol to be associated with the hydrocarbon region is slightly greater than for the hydroxyl group. Increasing the pressure enhances the solvation of methane into the aqueous phase and forces methanol further into the methane phase. As one continues to increase the pressure of the system, the phase separation is in- hibited and the solutes are found in distinct water cavities or c!athrates. 237 0009-261419l/$ 03.50 1991 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. Results and discussion 3.1. Water/methane The high concentration of methane coupled with the high temperature and low pressure in simulation A forces the water structure to expel excess methane molecules and establish a two-phase system. This oc- curs well within the time allotted for equilibration of the system. The shape of the methane phase will de- pend on the concentration, surface tension and the periodic boundary conditions used. Inspection of co- ordinate projections revealed a cylindrical methane aggregate extending over the length of the simulation box. Given this shape of the methane assembly, we can evaluate distribution functions relative to this cylinder axis. Thus, a radial distribution function of an atom A perpendicular to the cylinder axis was cal- culated as PA(p)=(L/2AAo)<(l/p)H(p p)), (1) where p is the radius, L the dimensions of the sim- ulation box, NA the number of species A, and ~p the bin size of the radial distance. H denotes a function which is one if p p I <Thp and otherwise zero, with the brackets indicating an ensemble average. In fig. 1, this function is shown for methane and water ox- ygens. Here, we see the hydrocarbon cylinder as the region extending from 0 to 4 A. There is no internal structure of this assembly except for a slight buildup of methane densities at the sharp interface. The waters do not present such a well-delineated inter- face but extend roughly 1 A into the methane cyl- inder. No global structural ordering of water relative to the hydrocarbon phase is seen here. The aqueous 2. Simulations The interactions between molecules were assumed to be composed of pairwise additive potential func- tions between atomic sites. For water interaction, we used the simple-point-charge (SPC) water model constructed by Berendsen et a!. [11]. The methane molecule was taken to be a united atom with only one Lennard-Jones term centered on the carbon atom; the methyl group of methanol was likewise simplified to one site, but the OH group was treated explicitly. The Lennard-Jones interaction coeffi- cients and alcohol charges were taken from the pa- rameter sets of Jorgensen and co-workers [12,131. The equations of motion were integrated using the velocity Verlet algorithm [141 with a timestep of 1.0 fs. The molecules were treated as rigid, and the in- ternal bond and angles were maintained by a shake- and-rattle scheme [15]. The temperature was kept at 300 K by periodic rescaling of the velocities. TwD systems of different molecular composition were studied under varying pressure: system 1 con- taining 107 waterand 18 methane molecules (A C); and system 2 in which seven of the waters were re- placed by methanol molecules (D F). The initial configurations were constructed from a water lattice with the solutes placed as far apart from each other as possible. Thus, each solute was initially sur- rounded by one layer of water molecules. Equilibra- tion times were typically 0.5 1.0 ns, allowing for the formation of any methane aggregate and ensuring that the solvent has ample time to adjust to the surround- ings. Sampling times after the equilibration varied from times similar to the equilibration up to 5.5 ns. The simulations are summarized in table 1. Table I Water/methane/methanol system properties 238 Volume 182, number 3,4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LE11 ERS 2 August 1991 ~A(P) Fig. 1. The radial distribution function of methane ( ), water oxygen atoms (), and water hydrogen atoms ( ) relative to the cylinder axis through the methane aggregate. Statistical un- certainty gives rise to the larger fluctuations close to the center of the cylinder. phase also supports individually solvated methane molecules. The surface waters structurally resemble water near a flat hydrocarbon surface [9,16,171. If we increase the pressure enough as in simulation C, the picture changes. It is no longer favorable for methane molecules to separate into a specific phase and instead they are solvated as small clusters in water cavities. This can also be seen in the pair dis B Fig. 2. The pair distribution function of methane methane in the water/methane system at low pressure (A) () and high pres- sure (C) ( ). tribution function of methane given in fig. 2. In the low-pressure system A, the distribution is dominated by methane pairs located in the pure hydrocarbon phase, and in accord with the structureless core seen in fig. 1, there is no long-range order. In the high- pressure system C, on the other hand, there is a sharp first peak indicating the nearest neighbor of the sol- vated cluster and a strong secondary peak of the nearest other methane cluster solvated in an adja- cent water cavity. In system C, the water structure changes from the typical tetrahedrally ordered net- work at low pressure into a Lennard-Jones fluid [18], but as seen in table 1, we can still have a large water water interaction energy associated with this P structure. 3.2. Water/methane/methanol Inclusion of a third component into the system was done in order to investigate both the stability of the two phases and solvation properties of the phases. Similarly, as in the low-pressure water/methane sys- tem A, two phases established themselves with the methanol molecules present in both phases. A snap- shot of the simulation (system D) is presented in fig. 3 as a coordinate projection where we look down the cylindrical axis in the unit box. A water-free region indicates where the methane-core region is located. Methanol molecules are, in this specific configura- tion, located on the outside of the methane phase with some solvation in the aqueous phase. Due to the low number of methanol molecules present and the large fluctuations of the equilibrium concentration of methanol in the phases, system D was sampled for 5.5 ns after an initial equilibration of 1.0 ns which established the two phases. Structurally, the methane core and aqueous solution resemble each other com- pared to the pure water/methane system. In order to probe the solvation of methanol in this system, we construct the corresponding potential of mean force, i.e. Gibbs free energy change, which is associated with bringing the molecules from infinite separation to a separation p relative to the cylinder axis, up to an additive constant, as WA(p)= kT1nPA(p)+C. (2) This function gives the influence of the solvent on 2 4 0Afr) 2 4 6 239 Volume 182, number 3,4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 2 August 1991 Fig. 3. Snapshot of a configuration from system D. Water oxy- gens are marked as open circles, methane as filled circles, and methanol atoms as larger, partially shaded circles. The view is of the unit simulation box looking down the methane-core cylinder axis. the dissolved species and is plotted for system D in fig. 4. In this representation, we see the methane core as a region with low energy separated from the bulk water phase by a 6 kJ/mole barrier for methane mol- ecules. Water penetration into the methane phase is WA(p) Fig. 4. Potential of mean force relative to the hydrocarbon cyl- inder axis for the species in system D, methane ( ), water oxygen ~ .), methanol methyl group ( ), and methanol hy- droxyl group ( ). accompanied by an increased cost in free energy, the further into the core one places the water molecule. For water, this is a steadily increasing function, whereas for methanol, we have a shallow minimum just outside the hydrocarbon-core/water interface. The cost of taking a methanol molecule from the aqueous phase and placing it inside the methane core is on the order of kT. The minima in the potential of mean force for the hydroxyl and methyl groups just outside the methane-core cylinder indicate a weak preferential ordering of methanol with the hy- drophobic part pointing towards the methane phase, and the hydrophilic part fully solvated within the aqueous phase. Increasing the pressure of the system enhances the solvation of methane molecules in the aqueous phase with a concomitant decrease of the hydrocarbon-cy!- inder diameter. For the systems B and Eat 1.7 and 1.8 kbar, respectively, the methane core has con- tracted 1 A but still retains the original features of the low-pressure system, i.e. a local ordering of methanes only at the edge of the cylinder and a rather diffuse methane solvation in the aqueous phase. In fig. 5, we show the methane and oxygen distribution relative to the cylinder axis for the water/methane! methanol system D at 0.2 kbar and system Eat 1.8 kbar. The water interface is somewhat sharper at B P Fig. 5. The radial distribution of methane and oxygen relative to the cylindrical axis through the methane aggregate for the watery methane/methanol system at two different pressures. Methane at 0.2 kbar ( ), and 1.8 kbar ( ); water oxygen at 0.2 kbar(),andl.8kbar( ). 0 2 4 6 8 p 240 Volume 182, number 3,4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 2 August 1991 higher pressure but there is still appreciable water penetration into the first methane layer of the cyl- inder. The solvation of methanol, and particularly the methyl part, into the hydrocarbon cylinder is en- hanced. In fact, the potential of mean force indicates that the solvent-averaged force on the methanol mol- ecule is always directed towards the center of the methane phase, in contrast to the low-pressure sys- tem in fig. 4, where there was a shallow minimum just outside the methane core. Again, increasing the pressure further, as in system F, prevents the for- mation of a separate methane phase. References Ill C. Conclusions For a range of systems composed of water, meth- ane and methanol, the excess of methane not so!- vated in an aqueous phase forms a separate phase. In the phase-separated systems, water does not dis- play any tendency to order itself with respect to the hydrocarbon phase. The methane molecules inside the cylindrical core display no strong correlation among themselves. The free energy barrier separat- ing methane inside the cylinder from the aqueous phase is 6 kJ/mole. Methanol is solvated over the entire system with only a weak preferential location just outside the methane core in the low-pressure systems. Raising the pressure forces the methanol molecules into the methane phase. A further increase of the pressure eventually forces the separate sol- vation of methane and methanol into the aqueous phase. At this elevated pressure, the system resem- bles a mixture of Lennard-Jones molecules where methane and water are fully miscible. 241 ems B and Eat 1.7 and 1.8 kbar, respectively, the methane core has con- tracted 1 A but still retains the original features of the low-pressure system, i.e. a local ordering of methanes only at the edge of the cylinder and a rather diffuse methane solvation in the aqueous phase. In fig. 5, we show the methane and oxygen distribution relative to the cylinder axis for the water/methane! methanol system D at 0.2 kbar and system Eat 1.8 kbar. The water interface is somewhat sharper at B P Fig. 5. The radial distribution of methane and oxygen relative to the cylindrical axis through the methane aggregate for the watery methane/methanol system at two different pressures. Methane at 0.2 kbar ( ), and 1.8 kbar ( ); water oxygen at 0.2 kbar(),andl.8kbar( ). 0 2 4 6 8 p 240 Volume 182, number 3,4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 2 August 1991 higher pressure but there is still appreciable water penetration into the first methane layer of the cyl- inder. The solvation of methanol, and particularly the methyl part, into the hydrocarbon cylinder is en- hanced. In fact, the potential of mean force indicates that the solvent-averaged force on the methanol mol- ecule is always directed towards the center of the methane phase, in contrast to the low-pressure sys- tem in fig. 4, where there was a shallow minimum just outside the methane core. Again, increasing the pressure further, as in system F, prevents the for- mation of a separate methane phase. References Ill C. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Computer simulations of an initially disordered molecular fluid composed of water and methane exhibit a phase-separation into a cylindrical core of methane molecules surrounded by an aqueous phase. A water/methane/methanol system also supports two phases, with only a weak preferential solvation of the methyl part of methanol into the hydrocarbon-core region. Increasing the pressure decreases the size of the hydrocarbon cylinder but increases the solvation of methanol into the methane phase. At sufficiently high pressures, the phase separation is inhibited by a formation of small methane clusters into water cavities or clathrates.
